=== Tourism ===

I Love New York (stylized as I ❤ NY) is a slogan, a logo, and state song that are the basis of an advertising campaign used since 1977 to promote tourism in the New York state, including New York City. The trademarked logo is owned by New York State Empire State Development. The Broadway League reported that Broadway shows sold approximately $1.27 billion worth of tickets in the 2013–2014 season, an 11.4% increase from $1.139 billion in the 2012–2013 season. Attendance in 2013–2014 stood at 12.21 million, representing a 5.5% increase from the 2012–2013 season's 11.57 million.


=== Exports ===
New York exports a wide variety of goods such as prepared foods, computers and electronics, cut diamonds, and other commodities. In 2007, the state exported a total of $71.1 billion worth of goods, with the five largest foreign export markets being Canada ($15 billion), the United Kingdom ($6 billion), Switzerland ($5.9 billion), Israel ($4.9 billion), and Hong Kong ($3.4 billion). New York's largest imports are oil, gold, aluminum, natural gas, electricity, rough diamonds, and lumber. The state also has a large manufacturing sector that includes printing and the production of garments, mainly in New York City; and furs, railroad equipment, automobile parts, and bus line vehicles, concentrated in Upstate regions.
New York is the nation's third-largest grape producing state, and third-largest wine producer by volume, behind California and Washington. The southern Finger Lakes hillsides, the Hudson Valley, the North Fork of Long Island, and the southern shore of Lake Erie are the primary grape- and wine-growing regions in New York, with many vineyards. In 2012, New York had 320 wineries and 37,000 grape bearing acres (15,000 ha), generating full-time employment for nearly 25,000 and annual wages over $1.1 billion, and yielding $4.8 billion in direct economic impact from New York grapes, grape juice, and wine and grape products.


=== Agriculture ===
The New York agriculture industry is a major producer overall, ranking among the top five states for agricultural products including maple syrup, apples, cherries, cabbage, dairy products, onions, and potatoes. The state is the largest producer of cabbage in the U.S. The state has about a quarter of its land in farms and produced $3.4 billion in agricultural products in 2001. The south shore of Lake Ontario provides the right mix of soils and microclimate for many apple, cherry, plum, pear and peach orchards. Apples are also grown in the Hudson Valley and near Lake Champlain. A moderately sized saltwater commercial fishery is located along the Atlantic side of Long Island. The principal catches by value are clams, lobsters, squid, and flounder.


=== Energy ===

In 2017, the State of New York consumed 156,370 gigawatthours (GWh) of electrical energy. Downstate regions (Hudson Valley, New York City, and Long Island) consumed 66% of that amount. Upstate regions produced 50% of that amount. The peak load in 2017 was 29,699 MW. The resource capability in 2017 was 42,839 MW. The NYISO's market monitor described the average all-in wholesale electric price as a range (a single value was not provided) from $25 per MWh to $53 per MWh for 2017.


== Education ==

Among all New York-based colleges and universities, Cornell University in Ithaca and Columbia University in Upper Manhattan, both Ivy League universities, are the most selective universities, and both are world-renowned private universities. New York University in Manhattan also ranks highly among New York state-based universities. Other notable large private universities include Syracuse University and Fordham University. Smaller notable private institutions of higher education include University of Rochester, Rockefeller University, Mercy University, New York Institute of Technology, Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, Yeshiva University, and Hofstra University. There are also a multitude of postgraduate-level schools in the State of New York, including medical, law, and engineering schools such as New York Medical College and New York Law School.
The United States Military Academy at West Point, the service academy of the U.S. Army, is located just south of Newburgh, on the west bank of the Hudson River. The federal Merchant Marine Academy is at Kings Point on Long Island.
In post-secondary education, the statewide public university system is the State University of New York (SUNY). The SUNY system consists of 64 community colleges, technical colleges, undergraduate colleges, and doctoral-granting institutions. The SUNY system has four \"university centers\": Albany (1844), Buffalo (1846), Binghamton (1946), and Stony Brook (1957), of which Buffalo and Stony Brook are the two flagship universities. The SUNY system is home to three academic medical centers: Renaissance School of Medicine at Stony Brook University on Long Island, Norton College of Medicine at SUNY Upstate Medical University in Syracuse, and SUNY Downstate Medical Center in Brooklyn.
The City University of New York is the public university system of New York City. It is the largest urban university system in the United States, comprising 25 campuses: eleven senior colleges, seven community colleges and seven professional institutions. While its constituent colleges date back as far as 1847, CUNY was established in 1961. The university enrolls more than 275,000 students, and counts thirteen Nobel Prize winners and twenty})

(:__Chunk__ {n_tokens: 1200,id: 4ff44119ec20f0f80ad2fc64010d6bd6,text:  Syracuse, and SUNY Downstate Medical Center in Brooklyn.
The City University of New York is the public university system of New York City. It is the largest urban university system in the United States, comprising 25 campuses: eleven senior colleges, seven community colleges and seven professional institutions. While its constituent colleges date back as far as 1847, CUNY was established in 1961. The university enrolls more than 275,000 students, and counts thirteen Nobel Prize winners and twenty-four MacArthur Fellows among its alumni.
A number of selective private liberal arts institutions are located in New York. Among them are Adelphi University, Bard College, Barnard College, Colgate University, Hamilton College, Hobart and William Smith Colleges, Marist College, Sarah Lawrence College, Skidmore College, St. Lawrence University, Union College, and Vassar College. Two of these schools, Barnard and Vassar, are members of the selective Seven Sisters, originally all women's colleges with ties to the Ivy League. Barnard is affiliated with Columbia University, its Manhattan neighbor, and Vassar became coeducational in 1969 after declining an offer to merge with Yale University.
New York is also home to what are widely regarded as the best performing arts schools in the world. The Juilliard School, located in the Upper West Side of Manhattan, is one of the world's leading music and dance schools. The Eastman School of Music, a professional school within the University of Rochester, was ranked first among U.S. music schools by U.S. News & World Report for five consecutive years.
The University of the State of New York accredits and sets standards for elementary, middle-level, and secondary education in the state, while the New York State Education Department oversees public schools and controls their standardized tests. The New York City Department of Education manages the New York City Public Schools system. In 1894, reflecting general racial discrimination then, the state passed a law that allowed communities to set up separate schools for children of African-American descent. In 1900, the state passed another law requiring integrated schools. During the 2013 fiscal year, New York spent more on public education per pupil than any other state, according to U.S. Census Bureau statistics.


== Transportation ==

New York has one of the oldest and most extensive transportation infrastructures in the country. Engineering challenges posed by the complex terrain of the state and the unique infrastructural issues of New York City brought on by urban crowding have had to be overcome perennially. Population expansion of the state has followed the path of the early waterways, first the Hudson River and Mohawk River, then the Erie Canal. In the 19th century, railroads were constructed along the river valleys, followed by the New York State Thruway in the 20th century.


=== Roads and highways ===
The New York State Department of Transportation (NYSDOT) is the department of the government of New York responsible for the development and operation of highways, railroads, mass transit systems, ports, waterways, and aviation facilities within the State of New York. The NYSDOT is headquartered at 50 Wolf Road in Colonie, Albany County. The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey (PANYNJ) is a joint venture between the states of New York and New Jersey and authorized by the U.S. Congress, established in 1921 through an interstate compact, that oversees much of the regional transportation infrastructure, including bridges, tunnels, airports, and seaports, within the geographical jurisdiction of the Port of New York and New Jersey. This 1,500 sq mi (3,900 km2) port district is generally encompassed within a 25 mi (40 km) radius of the Statue of Liberty National Monument. The Port Authority is headquartered at 4 World Trade Center in Lower Manhattan.
The New York State Department of Motor Vehicles (NYSDMV or DMV) is the governmental agency responsible for registering and inspecting automobiles and other motor vehicles, as well as licensing drivers in the State of New York. As of 2008, the NYSDMV has 11,284,546 drivers licenses on file and 10,697,644 vehicle registrations in force. All gasoline-powered vehicles registered in the State of New York are required to have an emissions inspection every 12 months, in order to ensure that environmental quality controls are working to prevent air pollution. Diesel-powered vehicles with a gross weight rating over 8,500 pounds that are registered in most Downstate New York counties must get an annual emissions inspection. All vehicles registered in the State of New York must get an annual safety inspection.


=== Public transportation ===
In addition to the New York City Subway system, which is confined to the five boroughs of New York City, New York state has four suburban commuter railroad systems that enter and depart the city: the Long Island Rail Road, Metro-North Railroad, Port Authority Trans-Hudson, and five of New Jersey Transit's rail lines. The New York City Department of Transportation (NYCDOT) is the agency of the government of New York City responsible for the management of much of New York City's own transportation infrastructure. In Buffalo, the Niagara Frontier Transportation Authority runs the Buffalo Metro Rail light-rail system; in Rochester, the Rochester Subway operated from 1927 until 1956, but fell into disuse as state and federal investment went to highways.


=== Airports ===
Portions of the transportation system are intermodal, allowing travelers to switch easily from one mode of transportation to another. One of the most notable examples is AirTrain JFK which allows rail passengers to travel directly to terminals at John F. Kennedy International Airport and to the underground New York City Subway system.


== Government ==

The Government of New York embodies the governmental structure of the State of New York as established by the New York State Constitution.})

=== Airports ===
Portions of the transportation system are intermodal, allowing travelers to switch easily from one mode of transportation to another. One of the most notable examples is AirTrain JFK which allows rail passengers to travel directly to terminals at John F. Kennedy International Airport and to the underground New York City Subway system.


== Government ==

The Government of New York embodies the governmental structure of the State of New York as established by the New York State Constitution. It is composed of three branches: executive, legislative, and judicial.
The governor is the state's chief executive and is assisted by the lieutenant governor. Both are elected on the same ticket. Additional elected officers include the attorney general and the comptroller. The secretary of state, formerly an elected officer, is currently appointed by the governor.
The New York State Legislature is bicameral and consists of the New York State Senate and the New York State Assembly. The state assembly consists of 150 members, while the state senate varies in its number of members, currently having 63. The legislature is empowered to make laws, subject to the governor's power to veto a bill. However, the veto may be overridden by the legislature if there is a two-thirds majority in favor of overriding in each house. The permanent laws of a general nature are codified in the Consolidated Laws of New York.

The highest court of appeal in the Unified Court System is the Court of Appeals whereas the primary felony trial court is the County Court (or the Supreme Court in New York City). The New York Supreme Court also acts as the intermediate appellate court for many cases, and the local courts handle a variety of other matters including small claims, traffic ticket cases, and local zoning matters, and are the starting point for all criminal cases.
The state is divided into counties, cities, towns, and villages, all of which are municipal corporations with respect to their own governments, as well as various corporate entities that serve single purposes that are also local governments, such as school districts, fire districts, and New York state public-benefit corporations, frequently known as authorities or development corporations. Each municipal corporation is granted varying home rule powers as provided by the New York Constitution. The state also has 10 Indian reservations. There have been several movements regarding secession from the state of New York. Proposals have included a state of Long Island, consisting of everything on the island outside New York City; a state called Niagara, the western counties of the state of New York; the northern counties of the state of New York called Upstate New York; making the city of New York a state; a proposal for a new Peconic County on eastern Long Island; and for the borough of Staten Island to secede from New York City.
In a 2020 study, New York was ranked as the 17th easiest state for citizens to vote in.
New York's government released a new seal, coat of arms, and flag in April 2020, adding \"E pluribus unum\" below the state's motto. A bill utilizing newly designed flag, arms and seal went into effect in September.
Revived in the early 2000s, Abolition Commemoration Day, also known as the Fifth of July, is a historic celebration commemorating the abolishment of slavery in New York. In July 2020, the New York State Assembly passed legislation officially recognizing Abolition Commemoration Day and Juneteenth in New York. Abolition Commemoration Day is observed on the second Monday in July and Juneteenth on June 19.


=== Capital punishment ===

Capital punishment was reintroduced in 1995 under the Pataki administration, but the statute was declared unconstitutional in 2004, when the New York Court of Appeals ruled in People v. LaValle that it violated the state constitution. The remaining death sentence was commuted by the court to life imprisonment in 2007, in People v. John Taylor, and the death row was disestablished in 2008, under executive order from Governor David Paterson. No execution has taken place in New York since 1963. Legislative efforts to amend the statute have failed, and death sentences are no longer sought at the state level, though certain crimes that fall under the jurisdiction of the federal government are subject to the federal death penalty.


=== Federal representation ===

New York is represented by Chuck Schumer and Kirsten Gillibrand in the United States Senate. There are twenty-six congressional districts, the nation's fourth highest number of congressional districts, behind California's 52, Texas's 38, and Florida's 28. As of 2024, fifteen districts are represented by members of the Democratic Party, while ten are represented by Republicans. Representation was reduced from 27 in 2023 due to the state's slower overall population growth relative to the overall national population growth. New York has 28 electoral votes in national presidential elections, a drop from its peak of 47 votes from 1933 to 1953.
The state has a strong imbalance of payments with the federal government. According to the New York State Comptroller, the State of New York received 91 cents in services for every $1 it sent in taxes to the U.S. federal government in the 2013 fiscal year; New York ranked in 46th place in the federal balance of payments to the state on a per capita basis.


== Politics ==

As of April 2016, the Democrats represented a plurality of voters in the State of New York, constituting more than twice as many registered voters as any other political party affiliation or lack thereof. No Republican presidential candidate has won over New York State since Ronald Reagan's landslide victory in 1984. New York City, as well as the state's other major urban locales, are significant Democratic strongholds. Rural portions of upstate New York, however})

(:__Chunk__ {n_tokens: 1200,id: e79cf35abe5fe1c8ee19e0dddf0f4283,text:  a per capita basis.


== Politics ==

As of April 2016, the Democrats represented a plurality of voters in the State of New York, constituting more than twice as many registered voters as any other political party affiliation or lack thereof. No Republican presidential candidate has won over New York State since Ronald Reagan's landslide victory in 1984. New York City, as well as the state's other major urban locales, are significant Democratic strongholds. Rural portions of upstate New York, however, are generally more conservative than large cities and tend to favor Republicans. Heavily populated suburban areas downstate, such as Westchester County and Long Island, were solidly Republican until the 1990s, but have since shifted to primarily supporting the Democratic Party.
New York City is the most important source of political fundraising in the United States for both major parties. Four of the top five ZIP Codes in the nation for political contributions are in Manhattan. The top ZIP Code, 10021 on the Upper East Side, generated the most money for the 2000 presidential campaigns of both George W. Bush and Al Gore.
The State of New York has the distinction of being the home state for both major-party nominees in three presidential elections. The 1904 presidential election saw former New York Governor and incumbent President Theodore Roosevelt face Alton B. Parker, chief judge of the New York Court of Appeals. The 1944 presidential election had Franklin D. Roosevelt, following in his cousin Theodore's footsteps as former New York Governor and incumbent president running for re-election against the then-incumbent New York Governor Thomas E. Dewey. In the 2016 presidential election, former United States Senator from New York Hillary Clinton, a resident of Chappaqua, was the Democratic Party nominee. The Republican Party nominee was businessman Donald Trump, a resident of Manhattan and a native of Queens.
New York City is an important center for international diplomacy. The United Nations headquarters is situated on the East Side of Midtown Manhattan since 1952.


== Sports ==

The State of New York is geographically home to one National Football League team, the Buffalo Bills, based in the Buffalo suburb of Orchard Park. Although the New York Giants and New York Jets represent the New York City metropolitan area and were previously located in New York City, they play in MetLife Stadium, located in East Rutherford, New Jersey. New York also has two Major League Baseball teams, the New York Yankees (based in the Bronx) and the New York Mets (based in Queens). Minor league baseball teams also play in the State of New York, including the Long Island Ducks, the Staten Island FerryHawks, and the Brooklyn Cyclones, downstate, and the Rochester Red Wings, the Binghamton Rumble Ponies, the Syracuse Mets, the Auburn Doubledays, the Batavia Muckdogs, the Hudson Valley Renegades and the Buffalo Bisons upstate.
New York is home to three National Hockey League franchises: the New York Rangers in Manhattan, the New York Islanders in Nassau County on Long Island, and the Buffalo Sabres in Buffalo. New York has two National Basketball Association teams, the New York Knicks in Manhattan, and the Brooklyn Nets in Brooklyn and a Women's National Basketball Association team, the New York Liberty, also based in Brooklyn. New York is the home of a Major League Soccer franchise, New York City FC, currently playing in the Bronx, though they are planning to build a new stadium in Queens. Although the New York Red Bulls represent the New York City metropolitan area, they play in Red Bull Arena in Harrison, New Jersey.

New York hosted the 1932 and 1980 Winter Olympics at Lake Placid. The 1980 Games are known for the USA–USSR ice hockey match dubbed the \"Miracle on Ice\", in which a group of American college students and amateurs defeated the heavily favored Soviet national ice hockey team 4–3 and went on to win the gold medal against Finland. Along with St. Moritz, Switzerland and Innsbruck, Austria, Lake Placid is one of the three cities to have hosted the Winter Olympic Games twice. New York City bid for the 2012 Summer Olympics but lost to London. The annual United States Open Tennis Championships is one of the world's four Grand Slam tennis tournaments and is held at the National Tennis Center in Flushing Meadows–Corona Park in Queens. The Belmont Stakes, part of the Triple Crown of Thoroughbred Racing, is held at Belmont Park in Nassau County on Long Island.
Several U.S. national sports halls of fame are or have been situated in New York. The National Baseball Hall of Fame and Museum is located in Cooperstown, Otsego County. The National Museum of Racing and Hall of Fame in Saratoga Springs, Saratoga County, honors achievements in the sport of thoroughbred horse racing. The physical facility of the National Soccer Hall of Fame in Oneonta, also in Otsego County, closed in 2010, although the organization itself has continued inductions.
The state of New York is also home to many intercollegiate division 1 sports programs. The State University of New York's flagship University at Buffalo are the Buffalo Bulls. Syracuse University's intercollegiate teams are the Syracuse Orange.
New York's strong sports background has influenced local industries such as sports betting as well. Due to the high volume of residents, tourists, and sports to bet on, New York became the first state to take in over $2 billion in sports bets in a single month.

(:Geo:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 0,description: Washington, D.C. is the capital city and federal district of the United States, situated on the Potomac River and bordered by Maryland and Virginia. It serves as a leading center for national and international research organizations, particularly think tanks focused on public policy. The city is renowned for its significant political and historical landmarks, including government buildings, monuments, and museums, which reflect its rich history and cultural significance.

Washington, D.C. is notable for its diverse population and high median income, as well as its substantial federal government employment. The city has a planned layout divided into four quadrants: Northwest (NW), Northeast (NE), Southeast (SE), and Southwest (SW). It is also recognized for its federal representation issues and the high federal tax contributions made by its residents.

Historically, Washington, D.C. has been the site of pivotal events, such as the inauguration of President George Washington and the first session of the Supreme Court of the United States. The city is characterized by numerous parks and cultural sites, making it a vibrant destination for both residents and visitors. Overall, Washington, D.C. stands out as a significant hub of political history and cultural diversity in the United States.,id: d641ff5c96564730960578ca5a055d75})

(:Geo:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 1,description: The United States is a country located in North America, with Washington, D.C. serving as its capital. It became a significant entity in 1848 when California was incorporated following the Mexican-American War. Additionally, the United States was involved in an arbitration ruling in 1872 that favored its interests concerning a border dispute with British Columbia. The establishment of a national capital was mandated by the Constitution to ensure effective governance and security for the nation.,id: a9f3b8cd50af42009093a243a00ff32f})

(:Person:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 2,description: George Washington was the first President of the United States and a pivotal figure in the founding of the nation. Washington's legacy is further commemorated by the capital city, Washington, D.C., which is named in his honor.,id: baca3917805947b3b8d206e9b0cf6f8b})

(:Geo:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 3,description: The Potomac River is a major river that flows through Washington, D.C., serving as a significant geographical feature and a natural boundary between the city and Virginia. It plays a crucial role as a transportation route and provides a scenic backdrop for various developments, including the Wharf. Historically, the Potomac River is notable as the location where the national capital was approved to be established under the Residence Act of 1790. Additionally, it is recognized as the lowest point in Washington, D.C., further emphasizing its importance to the city's geography and development.,id: 4c32d07d9bb14228a07d6c463149525c})

(:Geo:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 4,description: Maryland is a U.S. state known for its consistent support of the Democratic Party in elections. It shares land borders with Washington, D.C. to the north and east, making it geographically significant in relation to the nation's capital. Additionally, Maryland has been proposed as the neighboring state for retroceding the District of Columbia, a move aimed at providing normal state representation for residents of D.C.,id: a20d4ee589124c2fa1bb595c6d76a280})

(:Geo:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 5,description: Virginia is a U.S. state located across the Potomac River from Washington, D.C. It has a rich historical background, having been part of the territory involved in the Beaver Wars, during which Iroquois campaigns extended into the region. This highlights Virginia's significance in both geographical and historical contexts within the United States.,id: 2610339462b24b6c9826e217c6ffe661})

(:Geo:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 6,description: The Capitol Building is a significant government structure located in Washington, D.C., serving as the seat of the United States Congress. It holds historical importance, having been set on fire by British forces during the War of 1812. This event underscores the building's role in American history and its resilience as a symbol of the nation's legislative authority.,id: c19f7b573c41468cab390b3150d30ca7})

(:Geo:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 7,description: The National Mall is a large park located in downtown Washington, D.C. It serves as a central hub for tourism and is home to numerous iconic monuments and museums, including the Lincoln Memorial and the Washington Monument. The National Mall is a popular gathering place for both locals and visitors, offering a scenic and historical backdrop that showcases the rich cultural heritage of the United States.,id: cfd1914b4907483ea1f27d824d218377})

(:Person:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 8,description: Pierre Charles L'Enfant was a French-born military engineer and artist renowned for his role as the architect who designed the layout of Washington, D.C. in 1791. His vision for the city included a grand plan that incorporated wide avenues, public squares, and a systematic arrangement of streets, reflecting the ideals of the Enlightenment and the aspirations of the new nation.,id: ac719c7f91314c1ba4880ec5ca80c6bb})

(:Organization:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 9,description: The World Bank is an international financial institution headquartered in Washington, D.C., providing loans and grants to the governments of poorer countries.,id: f0e3431b162e45d0a918201a77e91016})

(:Organization:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 10,description: The International Monetary Fund is an organization headquartered in Washington, D.C. that aims to promote global economic stability and growth.,id: 6c8ea2e2b978408faf046c5d4c1b7d4f})

(:Organization:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 11,description: The Organization of American States is a continental organization founded in 1948, headquartered in Washington, D.C., aimed at regional solidarity and cooperation among its member states.,id: a21238637a9547d5a7cf5c428dc77c90})

(:Geo:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 12,description: The Capital District refers to a metropolitan area in New York State that includes the cities of Albany, Schenectady, and Troy. In this context, the Capital District is specifically associated with the New York State region, characterized by its urban centers and significance within the state.,id: cf2fab565445458ab094cfae21eea714})

(:Event:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 13,description: The 6th Congress was the legislative body that held its first session in the Capitol Building in Washington, D.C. in 1800.,id: a7bca53fe23a481389438541a4d57ee6})

(:Event:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 14,description: The Residence Act, adopted on July 16, 1790, approved the creation of the capital district along the Potomac River.,id: ff0eeab0dd0f43f9be64ceaf2cca4b99})

(:Event:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 15,description: The Pennsylvania Mutiny of 1783 was an event that forced Congress to move the capital temporarily to Princeton.,id: 376f0dc115484e05ac8f46b219bcca0b})
(:Event:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 16,description: Federalist No. 43 is an essay published by James Madison arguing for the need for a national capital.,id: 3493cd7f7a4446edb655e54307721b31})

(:Event:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 17,description: The Twenty-third Amendment to the United States Constitution was ratified in 1961. (:Geo:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 18,description: Alexandria is a city located in Virginia, to the south of Washington, D.C., across the Potomac River. It was included in the territory of the federal district, highlighting its historical significance and strategic location.,id: de1956064c684198bc7de9d9ca174fc7})

(:Geo:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 19,description: Georgetown is a historic neighborhood located in Washington, D.C. It is renowned for its old architecture, including notable structures such as the Old Stone House, which was built in 1765. Georgetown was one of the original settlements in the area and was founded in 1751. In 1895, it was merged with the City of Washington, becoming part of the federal district. This rich history and architectural significance contribute to Georgetown's unique character and cultural heritage.,id: 28331f2d024e4d228038d69ac95882b5})

(:Geo:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 20,description: The Northeast Megalopolis is an extensive urbanized region located in the northeastern United States, spanning from New Hampshire to Virginia. This densely populated area includes major cities such as New York City and its surrounding suburbs, as well as Washington, D.C. The region is characterized by its significant urban development and high population density, making it one of the most important and influential metropolitan areas in the country.,id: bbe56e991cdd4f92b0170a3182978a6f})

(:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 21,description: The District of Columbia is the federal district that was organized under the District of Columbia Organic Act of 1801.,id: 6ea1854c0e17477e9dd8b92ac5d184f5})

(:Event:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 22,description: The Pennsylvania Mutiny of 1783 was a significant event that highlighted the need for a national capital to ensure the security of the federal government.,id: 5b48102bb4984ebebcd4925a0c17d2e5})

(:Person:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 23,description: James Madison was one of the key figures who agreed to the establishment of the national capital in the Southern United States as part of the Compromise of 1790.,id: 216b486e1e464565913f4661fe3dd471})

(:Person:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 24,description: Alexander Hamilton was a prominent New Yorker and a key figure in the early development of the United States. He advocated for a strong federal government and played a significant role in drafting the United States Constitution. Additionally, Hamilton participated in the Compromise of 1790, where he agreed to the establishment of the national capital in exchange for the federal government assuming the Revolutionary War debts. His contributions were instrumental in shaping the financial and political landscape of the nation.,id: 278ca14fc9554f3eb519250abf698bf3})

(:Person:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 25,description: Thomas Jefferson was a key participant in the Compromise of 1790, which involved the establishment of the national capital in the Southern United States.,id: 8c727b9e92394c3aa0d910798c69ab3e})

(:Person:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 26,description: Andrew Ellicott was a key figure in the development of Washington, D.C. After Pierre Charles L'Enfant was dismissed from the project, Ellicott was tasked with completing the design of the city, during which he revised the original plans. In addition to his role in the city's design, Ellicott served as the surveyor who led the team responsible for surveying the borders of the federal district. His contributions were instrumental in shaping the layout and boundaries of the nation's capital.,id: a5e6dd87d380490796015e7fa31e7238})

(:Person:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 27,description: Benjamin Banneker was an African American astronomer who assisted in surveying the borders of the federal district.,id: 9d7e354be0e545fab6cf50bbdeae1d23})

(:Geo:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 28,description: Washington is a U.S. state located in the Pacific Northwest, characterized by its diverse geography that includes temperate rainforests, the Cascade Range, mountains, urban areas, and semi-arid regions. Often referred to as \"The Evergreen State,\" Washington is known for its rich flora and fauna, as well as its significant agricultural contributions, including a variety of agricultural products and renowned wine production. The state was created from the Oregon Territory, with its boundaries established by the Oregon Treaty and subsequent arbitration in 1872.

Washington has a notable military presence and plays a crucial role in the economy and exports of the United States. It is recognized for its extensive transportation system and faces environmental challenges, particularly related to the cleanup of the Hanford Nuclear Reservation. The state has a history of significant population growth and is known for its political landscape, which has been dominated by Democratic governance and progressive legislation on social issues. Additionally, Washington is unique in that it does not impose a personal income tax, contributing to its economic growth.

Furthermore, Washington is also the name of the city established as the national capital, named in honor of President George Washington. Overall, the state embodies a blend of natural beauty, economic vitality, and a rich historical context.,id: bd2451b2ecb34b5987095ebe054c8b0c})

(:Geo:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 29,description: Columbia is the name given to the federal district, a poetic name for the United States, established on September 9, 1791.,id: 0e1160ac1a254444b0190ceaef6ba9ef})

(:Event:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 30,description: The War of 1812 was a conflict during which British forces invaded and occupied Washington, D.C., leading to the burning of government buildings.,id: 0e3d830a0eb043aca5aaa073c87cc409})

(:Geo:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 31,description: Bladensburg is the location where British forces defeated an American force before invading Washington during the War of 1812.,id: e24bf3b75b80456b912ec8c051d8e516})

(:Geo:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 32,description: The Treasury Building is another government building in Washington that was burned by British forces during the War of 1812.,id: 9bfc0d27b92b4ee989a76e65203fcb1d})

(:Geo:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 33,description: The White House is the official residence and workplace of the President of the United States, situated in Washington, D.C. (:Geo:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 298,description: California is a U.S. state located in North America, renowned for its diverse culture, geography, and economy. It is characterized by a wide range of landscapes, including mountains, deserts, and coastal areas, which contribute to its rich ecology and significant agricultural output, particularly in the Central Valley. The state has a vibrant entertainment industry, being the birthplace of Hollywood, and is also a major hub for technology and trade, with significant ports that facilitate international commerce.

Historically, California underwent significant exploration and colonization by Spanish and later Mexican authorities, and it became a pivotal area during the Gold Rush and the Bear Flag Revolt. The state has a diverse population and is known for its sanctuary policies for immigrants, as well as its liberal political climate, which is reflected in its significant Democratic voting patterns and various political movements advocating for independence.

California's economy is heavily reliant on agriculture, technology, and trade, making it the largest sub-national economy in the world. The state has also hosted multiple Olympic Games and is home to numerous sports and educational institutions. Additionally, California is recognized for its environmental movement, energy production, and extensive transportation networks, which address significant political issues such as water rights and infrastructure.

Overall, California is a region that has undergone substantial historical changes, including population growth and migration patterns, and it is traditionally divided into Northern and Southern California, each with its unique characteristics and contributions to the state's identity.,id: 56cbbfc7aec644d292acb8301655fc9b})

(:Geo:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 299,description: Oregon is a U.S. state located in the Pacific Northwest region, bordered to the north by Washington and to the south by California. It is known for its diverse landscapes, which include mountains, forests, and a stunning coastline. Oregon's territory played a significant role in the establishment of the boundary between Washington and British Columbia, a process formalized through the Oregon Treaty. The state experiences climatic influences from the Pacific Ocean, similar to its neighboring state, Washington.,id: 1e59b710ccea44e8abd3efaba10fbced})
(:Geo:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 300,description: Nevada is a U.S. state located to the east of California, sharing a border with it.,id: 2b3eb2c24b1c4208b67a7d8b289ecb47})
(:Geo:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 301,description: Arizona is a U.S. state located to the east of California, sharing a border with it.,id: b43fe1e6d0a5458aaa809e55eaf24477})

(:Geo:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 302,description: Baja California is a Mexican state located to the south of California, sharing an international border with it.,id: 42dca9c921ec42ac819f0910e8c0cb5b})

(:Geo:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 303,description: Sacramento is the capital city of California, having held this status since 1854, with a brief interruption in 1862. It is notable for being California's first incorporated city and serves as the political and governmental center of the state. Located in the Sacramento Valley, Sacramento plays a crucial role in the administration and governance of California.,id: 8719e230f0e84fdb8a0abe4babaeeccf})

(:Geo:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 304,description: Los Angeles is a major city located in the southern part of California. It is the most populous city in California and the second-most populous city in the United States. Known for its vibrant entertainment industry, Los Angeles is home to many major film studios and entertainment companies. The city has a diverse population and serves as a significant hub for various industries, including a notable presence of illegal immigrants. In addition to its cultural and economic significance, Los Angeles is set to host the 2028 Summer Olympics, marking the fourth time California has hosted the Olympic Games. Historically, the capital of California was briefly moved to Los Angeles in 1845. Overall, Los Angeles stands out as a dynamic and influential city in both the state and the nation.,id: 8cd2c648e782459badae0b398e3f7ec7})

(:Geo:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 305,description: San Francisco Bay is a large estuary located in California that connects to the Pacific Ocean. It is not only a vital natural feature but also a significant urban region known for its cultural and economic contributions. The bay serves as an important ecological habitat and plays a crucial role in the surrounding area's economy and lifestyle.,id: 3a575a22d301422d964a82102f5c41e4})

(:Geo:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 306,description: Greater Los Angeles is a populous metropolitan area in California, renowned for its vibrant entertainment industry. This urban region encompasses various cities and is well-connected by the Metrolink commuter rail system, facilitating transportation across the area.,id: f38f62f078384248a9db947f193d2683})

(:Geo:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 307,description: The Sierra Nevada is a prominent mountain range located in eastern California, renowned for its alpine climate and diverse ecosystems. It serves as a habitat for some of the oldest living trees on Earth and is a vital source of snowmelt that feeds the Sacramento and San Joaquin Rivers. The range is home to Mount Whitney, which is the highest peak in the contiguous United States. Additionally, the Sierra Nevada offers a variety of recreational opportunities, attracting visitors to its stunning landscapes and natural beauty.,id: cb302617a8b64e1fb8faeadbbb9ddaa6})

(:Event:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 308,description: The California Gold Rush began in 1848 and marked a pivotal moment in the state's history, leading to substantial social and demographic changes. Following the discovery of gold, a mass migration of people to California occurred, significantly impacting the state's development and resulting in a massive influx of settlers in 1849. This event not only spurred economic growth but also influenced the population dynamics of California, shaping its future trajectory.,id: cb95082085934735a07743dbd31681a4})

(:Person:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 309,description: The Indigenous tribes of California were diverse groups that inhabited the region prior to European colonization, with complex social structures and sustainable practices.,id: bf9cbc6d69dd4b11abd02755bd2f6de5})
(:Geo:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 310,description: Baja California is a Mexican state that shares an international border with California to the south.,id: 0f80463904c84138b720dd638da2e1d7})

(:Geo:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 311,description: California was one of the most culturally and linguistically diverse areas in pre-Columbian North America, home to many Indigenous tribes.,id: eab50c05dc1f4766b77e351336e19227})

(:Organization:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 312,description: The Spanish Empire was the colonial power that explored and settled California in the 16th and 17th centuries.,id: 71a1583d9e5149f78c16ce7aa5341b38})

(:Organization:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 313,description: Mexico plays a significant role in various aspects of the United States, particularly in relation to California and New York. As California's biggest trade partner, Mexico greatly influences the state's economy through robust trade relations. Additionally, Mexico is a major source of immigration, being one of the top countries of origin for immigrants in New York. Notably, more than half of California's illegal immigrants originate from Mexico, highlighting the country's impact on immigration patterns in the state. Historically, Mexico was also the territory that California belonged to after gaining independence from Spain in 1821, until it was ceded to the United States in 1848. This historical connection further underscores the deep ties between Mexico and California.,id: 543b9b5f7b1a43599d223f8fe2325750})

(:Person:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 314,description: The Indigenous peoples of California included more than 70 distinct ethnic groups with complex social structures and sustainable practices.,id: cd52beda44d6485999b0a021786d4b01})

(:Person:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 315,description: The Chumash are a Native American people indigenous to the coastal regions of California. They are recognized for their rich culture and history, which includes unique social structures and roles within their community. Notably, the term 'aqi refers to individuals who performed women's social roles among the Chumash. As one of the Indigenous tribes of California, the Chumash have a significant cultural heritage that continues to be celebrated and studied today.,id: cc19927ceeba4125ab35e8d2c1358b9f})

(:Person:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 316,description: The Pomo are another Indigenous tribe of California, recognized for their diverse languages and cultural practices.,id: 68f5eb2a40c04b57a300d7bc9deb6f43})
(:Person:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 317,description: The Salinan are an Indigenous tribe from California, known for their historical presence in the region.,id: d3cd23ecc03545aaa88a5d72d223b36d})

(:Organization:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 318,description: The California government is the governing body that recognized the benefits of controlled burning practices developed by Indigenous peoples in 2022.,id: 0d6804ffe33f454da03db6f19a5c1b69})

(:Event:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 319,description: Droughts are ongoing environmental issues faced by California, impacting its agriculture and water supply.,id: de985ec0c63e4a358a33bfba12e1e89e})

(:Event:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 320,description: Wildfires are a significant environmental concern in California, particularly during dry seasons when conditions are ripe for their occurrence. The 2018 wildfire season was especially devastating, resulting in widespread destruction and loss of life. These wildfires are often exacerbated by factors such as Santa Ana winds, which can intensify the spread of flames. Overall, the frequency and severity of wildfires in California are closely linked to climate conditions and ongoing drought, making them a persistent threat to both the environment and communities in the region.,id: 09fc227d2faa46cea64db8fe7b975c48})

(:Person:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 321,description: Juan Rodríguez Cabrillo was a Portuguese captain who led the first European maritime expedition to explore the coast of California in 1542, commissioned by the Viceroy of New Spain, Antonio de Mendoza.,id: 4ed9d8b7361948ae9dd47f181fa87093})

(:Person:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 322,description: Antonio de Mendoza was the Viceroy of New Spain who commissioned Juan Rodríguez Cabrillo to lead an expedition in search of trade opportunities along the Pacific coast.,id: 7d01922363084d27b1681198d271306d})

(:Person:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 323,description: Francis Drake was a privateer and explorer who explored and claimed parts of the California coast in 1579, landing north of what would become San Francisco.,id: 0e7db187c5bc4b83b36257f8c58286e1})

(:Geo:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 324,description: Morro Bay is a location in California where Filipino sailors arrived in Spanish ships in 1587, marking the first Asians to set foot on what would be the United States.,id: a385732b5ace4bccb848febc24876464})

(:Person:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 325,description: Caliph Hasan ibn Ali was a historical figure whose descendants transited through California on their way to Guerrero, Mexico, playing a role in the wars of independence.,id: be8c3f2138ae46d980c94f6f3234b7f5})

(:Person:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 326,description: Sebastián Vizcaíno was an explorer who mapped the coast of California in 1602 for New Spain, landing in Monterey.,id: e2f1cf8575d14185b5b2b0aea3847261})

(:Person:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 327,description: Gaspar de Portolá was the leader of the military and civil contingent of the Portolá expedition, which was pivotal in the Spanish colonization of California.,id: 81c1a07b8ba84a4da134f686a22f62a8})

(:Person:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 328,description: Junípero Serra was a Spanish missionary who led the religious component of the Portolá expedition and established the first missions in California.,id: 4879e820cbee4092a7b3237fc56bd168})

(:Event:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 329,description: Mission San Diego de Alcalá was the first religious settlement established by the Spanish in California in 1769.,id: 3d730c5d35f64c90a875a5f78a058b0e})

(:Event:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 330,description: The Presidio of San Diego was the first military settlement established by the Spanish in California, founded alongside Mission San Diego de Alcalá.,id: 6d12ae3c66c14b6da2f08b546210e78e})

(:Person:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 334,description: Gabriel Moraga was a member of the Anza expedition who named many of California's prominent rivers.,id: 14dca7853f0744f7a456f2b5b292b905})

(:Geo:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 335,description: San Jose is a prominent city located in California, recognized for its significant role in the state's history and development. As one of California's major cities, San Jose was among the first to be incorporated, highlighting its early importance in the region. Additionally, San Jose operates the VTA light rail system, which plays a crucial role in the public transportation network of the area, facilitating mobility for residents and visitors alike.,id: f18a67269a8c4badb62c79fd3845c020})

(:Event:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 350,description: The \"GOLD RUSH\" refers to the California Gold Rush, which began in 1848 and marked a pivotal moment in the state's history. Overall, the Gold Rush was a major migration event that not only increased California's population but also spurred significant economic growth in the mid-19th century, shaping the future of the region.,id: 201d5ddf286a4c41a231967efa48a0b1})

(:Person:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 585,description: Ronald Reagan is a former Republican President of the United States, serving as the 40th President from 1981 to 1989. (:Organization:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 586,description: The Democratic Party is a major political party in the United States, recognized as one of the two primary political parties in the country. It has maintained control over Washington's governorship and legislature for decades, showcasing its longstanding influence in the region. Additionally, the party has gained significant strength in California since 1990, reflecting its growing support in that state. Furthermore, the Democratic Party represents a plurality of voters in New York State, highlighting its substantial presence and impact in one of the nation's most populous states.,id: 1b4de337627d422b92833b2ae7376044})

(:Organization:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 587,description: The Republican Party is a major political party in the United States, recognized as one of the two primary political entities in the country. Historically, the party dominated California politics until the 1990s, showcasing its significant influence in that region. Additionally, the Republican Party has traditionally found favor in rural areas of New York State, reflecting its appeal in certain demographics. However, since the 1994 elections, the party has faced challenges in gaining control in Washington, indicating a shift in its political fortunes over the years.,id: 7d04a9175b77456b8bd4afd33bc24cac})

(:Geo:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 626,description: Cape Flattery is located at the entrance to the Strait of Juan de Fuca and was sighted by British explorer Captain James Cook in 1778.,id: e4745b25984b4de0ad2f71b8f56c9816})

(:Geo:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 627,description: The Strait of Juan de Fuca is a waterway that separates Vancouver Island from the Olympic Peninsula and was discovered in 1787.,id: eaf3a36516c44f55b7ba1e6f718138bf})

(:Organization:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 628,description: The Imperial Eagle was the ship captained by Charles William Barkley, who sighted the Strait of Juan de Fuca in 1787.,id: e795bea36c914c529f2b43c8d2a56b36})

(:Geo:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 633,description: The Columbia River is a major river located in the Pacific Northwest of the United States, primarily flowing through Washington and forming part of the boundary between Oregon and Washington. It plays a crucial role in the region's irrigation and agriculture, particularly in Eastern Washington, where it supports farming activities. The river also serves as a significant geographical boundary and influences the climate and ecology of the surrounding areas. Notably, the Wenatchee River joins the Columbia River, further contributing to its flow and ecological diversity.

In addition to its ecological and agricultural importance, the Columbia River provides navigable waterways that enhance the transportation infrastructure of Washington. Historically, the river was discovered by American captain Robert Gray, who named it after his ship, the Columbia, marking its significance in the region's exploration and history. Overall, the Columbia River is a vital natural resource that has shaped the geography, economy, and history of the Pacific Northwest.,id: 695e41d3998d4883ad359f273c89925c})

(:Event:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 634,description: The Lewis and Clark Expedition entered the state on October 10, 1805, exploring the newly acquired territories of the United States.,id: ddca58c9712d430eaa19d04bd093ebb9})
(:Person:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 635,description: David Thompson was an explorer who camped at the confluence of the Columbia and Snake Rivers in 1811.,id: 893bf5c73e66491fac837d486bce3688})

(:Organization:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 636,description: The Hudson's Bay Company was a fur trading company that played a significant role in the settlement and trade in the Columbia District.,id: 5b2622d152c64182a8fcaa08d3ffb35a})

(:Person:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 637,description: James Sinclair was a fur trapper who led settlers from the Red River Colony to the Columbia Valley in 1841.,id: 2cead377d7154e4dad7f4f73f2c4ffc1})

(:Geo:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 638,description: Fort Vancouver was a trading post established by the Hudson's Bay Company and was significant in the settlement of the region.,id: 51180f0ee3a24039ad58069cac2bfe78})

(:Event:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 639,description: The Whitman massacre in 1847 involved the execution of Marcus Whitman and twelve other settlers by the Cayuse Indians.,id: fee29a53e16c4005b0127de8ef14efed})

(:Person:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 640,description: Marcus Whitman was a missionary who established missions in the Oregon Territory and was executed during the Whitman massacre.,id: 6ec64577d90949f7b1efb03ec754ae5e})

(:Event:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 641,description: The Oregon Treaty of 1846 established the border between British North America and the United States along the 49th parallel.,id: 0e26e8f0127c446dae8655fee434de28})

(:Geo:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 642,description: The San Juan Islands are a group of islands located in Washington State, renowned for their rich marine life, which includes populations of killer whales, gray whales, and humpback whales. Historically, the islands were the focal point of a territorial dispute between the United States and Britain, a conflict that was ultimately resolved through arbitration in 1872.,id: 291ce51f207c46caaa304f50728b479f})

(:Person:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 643,description: Kaiser Wilhelm I of the German Empire was selected as an arbitrator to resolve the dispute over the San Juan Islands.,id: 0051d28397714bd3a1d640232f8aae19})

(:Event:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 644,description: The Monticello Convention was a significant event that took place in response to the increasing population in the Oregon Territory. It served as a platform for the residents of the Oregon Territory to formally request the establishment of Washington Territory. This convention played a crucial role in the eventual creation of Washington as a territory, highlighting the needs and aspirations of the growing population in the region.,id: a4aa192adebb4ef1929c9f9878f18dfc})
(:Event:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 645,description: The smallpox epidemic of the 1770s caused widespread devastation among the Native American population.,id: 330abd62f30844029123e1e8d87e9127})

(:Person:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 646,description: The Cayuse Indians were involved in the Whitman massacre and the subsequent Cayuse War against settlers.,id: 88e475f4d7a2499ca7d127641c934678})

(:Geo:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 658,description: Cowlitz County is a region in Washington that holds historical significance as the site of the Monticello Convention. (:Event:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 659,description: The Cayuse War was a conflict triggered by the Whitman massacre, involving settlers and the Cayuse Indians.,id: ecc2dde177dc44dabdc239002f9139dd})

(:Geo:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 663,description: British Columbia is a Canadian province located on the westernmost coast of the country, sharing a border with Alaska to the east. This geographical positioning significantly influences both the area's geography and economy. Historically, British Columbia was involved in a border dispute with the United States, which was ultimately resolved by the Oregon Treaty and subsequent arbitration in 1872. The province is often associated with the Pacific Northwest, reflecting its geographical proximity and similar climate to that region.,id: 96b4b1f288c6462786c5a58ed5d9750f})

(:Person:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 664,description: Millard Fillmore was the President of the United States who signed the legislation to create Washington Territory on March 2, 1853.,id: 78b47e9d61a349cd978c6ee49a2a1cb7})

(:Geo:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 665,description: The Grand Coulee Dam is the largest concrete structure in the United States, completed in 1941, and is significant for its role in hydroelectric power production along the Columbia River.,id: 277f7f95cc3241cd8dc01d2b7431cc11})

(:Geo:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 666,description: Seattle is a major city located in Washington state, recognized for its cold winters, with recorded temperatures dropping as low as 0 °F (−18 °C) and notable snowfall. The city has a rich history tied to its port and shipbuilding industry, playing a crucial role during World War II. Seattle is characterized by its diverse population and cultural significance, particularly within the African American and Asian American communities. It serves as the principal city of the Seattle metropolitan area and is home to Seattle-Tacoma International Airport, along with various transportation systems, including light rail and bus services. Additionally, Seattle is known for its high minimum wage and a significant business presence, contributing to its economic vitality. The city is situated near Mount Rainier, further enhancing its cultural and economic significance in the region.,id: e6605687c07f4a7991e6f79e541f468c})

(:Geo:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 667,description: Tacoma is a city in Washington that historically had large smelters for treating ores and was significant in the state's industrial development.,id: baa5c9072f7e46e18ba722f22e26137c})

(:Organization:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 668,description: The Boeing Company is an iconic aerospace manufacturer based in Washington that produced heavy bombers during World War II.,id: 844b1f9aaf6440bd89aee477c9a965d6})

(:Geo:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 669,description: The Hanford Works is an atomic energy plant in Eastern Washington that played a major role in the construction of atomic bombs during World War II.,id: 5a9d94de0a2040d1968cd1176304cbda})

(:Geo:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 670,description: Fort Lawton was a military installation in Seattle where soldiers were quartered during World War II, later becoming Discovery Park.,id: 655728e36af1497088dfd49959ec6f9d})

(:Geo:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 671,description: The Idaho Panhandle is a region that was initially included in the boundary of Washington Territory before the creation of Idaho Territory in 1863.,id: 8f07090587ca484dad72ccc3e569c64d})

(:Geo:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 672,description: The Cascade Range is a prominent mountain range located in Washington, characterized by its north-south orientation. This range is notable for its active volcanoes and plays a significant role in dividing the state into Western and Eastern regions. Additionally, the Cascade Range influences local weather patterns, particularly contributing to heavy snowfall on its western slopes.,id: 07401831b1364cf3bae0ed487dd45fc2})

(:Event:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 673,description: World War I was a global conflict during which the region around eastern Puget Sound developed heavy industry, contributing to Washington's economic growth.,id: 3b39f35349d34e79b7866f3d282549fd})

(:Event:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 674,description: World War II was a major conflict that focused war industries in Washington, including the production of warships and heavy bombers by Boeing.,id: 711a93a5bead476e91f4323739c05ecc})

(:Geo:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 675,description: Eastern Washington is a region of the state of Washington located east of the Cascade Range. It is known for its agricultural productivity, particularly in the cultivation of wheat and apple orchards. The region is characterized by semi-arid conditions, which contribute to a distinct flora compared to Western Washington. The landscape is dominated by tumbleweeds and sagebrush, reflecting the drier climate that defines Eastern Washington. Overall, this area is significant for its agricultural activities and unique environmental features.,id: 63e7a852b03f47a8b50b6d84220ab95e})

(:Geo:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 676,description: Western Washington is a region characterized by heavy rainfall and dense forests, contributing to the state's lumber industry.,id: d35c8cd8f1d748919a7f2d55d5ed8132})

(:Event:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 940,description: Natural resources play a crucial role in the economies and ecologies of various regions, exemplified by Alaska and New York. In Alaska, the state's abundant natural resources, particularly oil and natural gas, have a significant impact on its economy, driving growth and providing employment opportunities. Conversely, New York's natural resources encompass forests, water bodies, and wildlife, which not only contribute to the state's economy but also support its ecological balance. Together, these resources highlight the diverse ways in which natural assets can influence both economic development and environmental sustainability in different geographical contexts.,id: 57c916fb94694a5b9404f2aec7b360ce})

(:Event:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 941,description: Commercial fishing is a dominant industry in Alaska's economy, contributing to its high per capita income.,id: 46cfc8b82d4c4aefad6e21e6f9d402c4})

(:Geo:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 948,description: New York is a state located in the Northeastern United States, recognized for its diverse geography, rich history, and significant population, making it the fourth-most populous state in the U.S. It is home to a variety of ecosystems and climates, bordered by the Great Lakes and the Atlantic Ocean. New York boasts a diverse culture and is known for its substantial immigrant communities, including the largest Italian American and Greek American populations in the country.

The state is particularly famous for New York City, its most populous city, which serves as a major cultural, financial, and educational hub. New York City is renowned for its iconic landmarks, vibrant arts scene, and significant political influence. The state also has a notable tourism industry, attracting millions of residents and visitors alike. In recent years, New York has made headlines for its substantial sports betting activities, becoming the first state to exceed $2 billion in sports bets in a single month.

Overall, New York is characterized by its diverse economy, significant urban areas, and a wealth of cultural landmarks that contribute to its status as a prominent state in the United States.,id: 159f9d56a0b04e8cbf83b29cb31fce26})

(:Geo:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 949,description: New York City is a major global city located in the southeastern part of New York State and is the largest city in the United States. It is renowned for its significant cultural, financial, and political influence, making it a vital center for various sectors including commerce, tourism, and international diplomacy. As the most populous city in the country, New York City comprises five counties and is home to over two-fifths of the state's population, showcasing a rich cultural diversity and a vibrant economy.

Historically, New York City has played a crucial role in the immigration narrative of the United States, serving as a major ocean port and a gateway for millions of immigrants. It is also recognized for its historical significance in the LGBTQ+ rights movement and was the national capital under the Articles of Confederation, contributing to the early formation of the United States government during the American Revolution.

In addition to its cultural and historical importance, New York City is a global center for trading in public equity and debt capital markets, highlighting its economic power and development. The city is famous for its iconic attractions, including Broadway shows, which draw millions of tourists each year, further solidifying its status as a major cultural and economic hub.,id: 262cdec98df148bead39a5c37a5374db})

(:Geo:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 950,description: Albany is a city located in the eastern part of New York State along the Hudson River. It serves as the capital of New York and is recognized as the sixth-largest city in the state. Historically, Albany played a significant role during the early colonial period, marked by the establishment of Fort Nassau and Fort Orange. In contemporary times, Albany is part of the Tech Valley region, contributing to the state's high-tech industry. The city is also known for its rich historical significance and government institutions. Additionally, Albany has a diverse community, notably comprising a large population of ethnic Italians and Irish Americans.,id: deeabadc67de4a4c912bbf0aef3a06e5})

(:Organization:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 951,description: Columbia University is an Ivy League research university situated in Upper Manhattan, New York City. It is renowned for its rigorous and prestigious academic programs, attracting a diverse student body and producing notable alumni. The university's reputation for excellence in education and research solidifies its status as one of the leading institutions of higher learning in the United States.,id: cfa08d0343344fde9647079f5daf7026})

(:Organization:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 952,description: Cornell University is an Ivy League institution located in Ithaca, New York, renowned for its selectivity and academic excellence. The university is actively involved in various research initiatives, particularly in technology and applied sciences, with significant activities also taking place in New York City. Cornell is recognized for its diverse academic offerings, which contribute to its reputation as a leading educational establishment.,id: e6cb3da7efb74ddd9e1cd6f80ec7d118})

(:Organization:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 953,description: The State University of New York (SUNY) is a large public university system in New York, comprising multiple campuses across the state.,id: 53d25682fc3747fd99ea05a9a62856c9})

(:Event:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 954,description: Times Square is a major commercial and entertainment hub in New York City, known for its bright lights and as a popular tourist destination.,id: 0ca64d38e45846b3a6db72d7d9ce685b})

(:Event:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 955,description: Central Park is a large public park in New York City, famous for its scenic landscapes and recreational opportunities.,id: 1ed9e840e0104c059b7e7a0293a27157})

(:Event:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 956,description: Niagara Falls is a renowned group of three waterfalls situated on the Niagara River, straddling the border between New York and Ontario, Canada. It is celebrated for its stunning natural beauty and serves as a major tourist attraction, drawing visitors from around the world. The falls are not only a remarkable natural wonder but also a significant landmark that highlights the picturesque landscape of the region.,id: 9ad663791dbc420998159819b4658989})

(:Event:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 957,description: Grand Central Terminal is a historic train station in New York City, known for its stunning architecture and as a major transportation hub.,id: 8b1e007207774fe3bd4d0e6ecadcfa5b})

(:Organization:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 958,description: The Algonquians are a group of Native American tribes that historically inhabited the northeastern United States, known for their diverse cultures and languages.,id: d77929442ffd481fb5011322639398e0})

(:Person:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 959,description: Henry Hudson was an English explorer known for his exploration of the northeastern coast of North America, including the river that bears his name.,id: cdb2e65badf6486d88d88677ddebd2b8})

(:Person:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 960,description: King Philip, also known as Metacomet, was a leader of the Wampanoag tribe who played a significant role in King Philip's War against English settlers.,id: fde9a34c2af54024aba5b57de8dda960})

(:Event:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 961,description: The Beaver Wars were a series of conflicts that took place in the 17th century, primarily from approximately 1640 to 1680. These wars involved various Native American tribes, with the Iroquois being the principal aggressors. The conflicts were primarily fought against Algonquian and Siouan tribes, as the Iroquois sought to gain control over the lucrative fur trade and secure land for animal trapping. The Beaver Wars were significant in shaping the dynamics of power and trade among Native American tribes during this period.,id: ac7eff4d46f440ea887c0e0c66b8d7e8})

(:Geo:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 962,description: The Adirondack Mountains are a mountain range in northeastern New York, known for their natural beauty and outdoor recreational opportunities.,id: d304bf63343d4a6fb1dcb89944a70091})

(:Geo:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 963,description: The Catskill Mountains are a mountain range in southeastern New York, famous for their scenic landscapes and as a popular destination for hiking and tourism.,id: f0dc7ab9cf584f84bd2bdcb5427d4716})

(:Geo:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 964,description: The Finger Lakes are a group of lakes located in central New York, renowned for their picturesque beauty and as a popular tourist destination. This region is particularly famous for its wine production and grape-growing areas, attracting visitors who enjoy both outdoor activities and the local wine culture. The combination of stunning landscapes and a thriving wine industry makes the Finger Lakes a unique and appealing location for tourists and residents alike.,id: 0bb64dcd7db842269d7d898c5c125228})

(:Organization:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 965,description: The Susquehannock were a Native American tribe that historically inhabited the region around the Susquehanna River in Pennsylvania and New York. This tribe faced significant challenges during the French and Indian War, which led to their decimation. Following this period of conflict, the remnants of the Susquehannock were absorbed by Iroquoian peoples, marking a significant shift in their cultural and social structure.,id: 7be6b51000ab496aad017d843d5e5bfc})

(:Organization:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 966,description: The Mohawk are a Native American tribe that is part of the Iroquois Confederacy, recognized for their historical significance and rich cultural heritage. As one of the tribes within this confederacy, the Mohawk have played a crucial role in the history of the region, contributing to the social, political, and cultural dynamics of the area. Their legacy continues to be an important aspect of Native American history and identity.,id: 11c03a44d38c493d8fe69450f6687305})

(:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 967,description: The Iroquois Confederacy is a political alliance comprising several Native American tribes, specifically the Seneca, Cayuga, Onondaga, Oneida, Tuscarora, and Mohawk. This confederacy played a significant role in the history of North America, influencing both indigenous and colonial interactions in the region.,id: 7b1195e959e2449d8bdde63b664b0820})

(:Geo:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 968,description: Michigan is a U.S. state that was part of the territory involved in the Beaver Wars, where Iroquois campaigns extended.,id: 3df8072c4eea422b8d33d326a228ef6a})

(:Person:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 969,description: The Tuscarora are a Native American tribe that became the sixth nation of the Iroquois Confederacy after being offered shelter by the Iroquois.,id: 12bb7025c18545c9a3997ff6a09d8292})

(:Person:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 970,description: The Seneca are one of the tribes of the Iroquois Confederacy, known for their significant role in the history of the region.,id: a824898eb4ff40a4b6d5cd60fa19bf8d})

(:Person:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 972,description: The Onondaga are one of the tribes of the Iroquois Confederacy, known for their significant role in the history of the region.,id: d4b41836e8154842ad5baa87539aef69})

(:Person:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 974,description: William Penn was an English Quaker and the founder of Pennsylvania, who formed a close relationship with the Lenape tribe.,id: 2c32cb270b224c37ba19a615933e615e})

(:Person:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 975,description: The Lenape are a Native American tribe that formed a close relationship with William Penn but faced land loss after his death.,id: c533c9b4cd3244c489d9132cd8788a91})

(:Person:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 976,description: The Nanticoke are a Native American tribe that was relocated by the United States from the Delmarva Peninsula to former Iroquois lands.,id: c7b7194979af4aca803966e89c3c6813})

(:Event:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 977,description: The French and Indian War was a conflict that led to the decimation of the Susquehannock tribe and affected various Native American tribes in the region.,id: 4f52a767f62a44e68b80c091b43e2381})

(:Event:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 978,description: The American Revolution was a conflict in which the Iroquois fought for both sides, leading to significant changes in their population and alliances.,id: 0b07361d67714f81b5937abfcf072df7})

(:Organization:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 979,description: Fort Nassau was the first Dutch settlement in North America, established in 1614 near present-day Albany, serving as a trading post.,id: 654b45ff08dc4853b2b030b13fbfc1dc})

(:Organization:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 981,description: New Netherland was a Dutch colony in North America that included parts of present-day New York and New Jersey, known for its fur trade.,id: 39ad6cd5503347cf92e4bcaf47ddb232})

(:Organization:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 982,description: New Amsterdam was a Dutch settlement that later became New York City, significant for its role in trade and colonial governance.,id: 5a4439a3806142b788b4bdb0884adc06})

(:Person:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 983,description: Hendrick Corstiaensen was the commander who rebuilt Fort Nassau in 1614, marking the Dutch presence in North America.,id: 0899308481954f72b364e8710c5dc3ee})

(:Person:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 984,description: Giovanni da Verrazzano was an Italian explorer who explored the Atlantic coast of North America in 1524, including New York Harbor.,id: 9af2504c77fb4c5fb0b28b712eceda9b})

(:Organization:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 985,description: The Sons of Liberty were a group organized in New York City during the 1760s to oppose British taxation and played a key role in the American Revolution.,id: f267922a3dee4d9c9a98f602e7089562})

(:Event:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 986,description: The Stamp Act Congress was a meeting held in New York City on October 19, 1765, where representatives from the Thirteen Colonies gathered to discuss their grievances against British taxation.,id: 6893bd1ae27b4b899a0cd21ffcd2945a})

(:Event:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 987,description: The Battle of Long Island, also known as the Battle of Brooklyn, was the first major battle of the American Revolutionary War, taking place in August 1776.,id: 70179f06f846495dbb71762c48666f7d})

(:Organization:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 990,description: The Erie Canal is a historic waterway located in New York that connects the Hudson River to Lake Erie. Since its completion in the early 19th century, it has played a crucial role in facilitating trade and transportation, significantly contributing to the economic development of the state. The canal served as a vital link between New York City and the Great Lakes, enhancing trade routes and promoting commerce. This significant infrastructure project was championed by Governor DeWitt Clinton, highlighting its importance in the region's history and development.,id: ad8813296c094188991d88e1ebc1c56d})

(:Person:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 991,description: DeWitt Clinton was the Governor of New York who promoted the construction of the Erie Canal, which greatly impacted transportation and trade in the region.,id: 0186e179ec214e48910953153cd5bc83})

(:Event:__Entity__ {human_readable_id: 992,description: The Third Anglo-Dutch War was a conflict between England and the Dutch Republic from 1672 to 1674, which included the capture of New Orange.,id: 1180ae70676c49438e3e43006600f689})
